item.title: AWS Elastic Beanstalk & Go
item.author: mark@markrichman.com (Mark Richman)
item.description: I’ll show you how to easily deploy a Go web application using AWS Elastic Beanstalk and Go. If you’re not familiar, AWS Elastic Beanstalk lets you deploy your app to AWS, and it takes care of load balancing and auto-scaling for you. No server configuration required at all. Itâ€™s cool because it supports lots of platforms - Java, PHP, .NET, Node.js, Python, Ruby, Docker, and Go. I like working with Go

item.title: Hargo: Load Testing using .har files in Go
item.author: mark@markrichman.com (Mark Richman)
item.description: I’ve spent quite a bit of time working with Visual Studio’s web performance tests. While it’s easy to use, it’s not as flexible or extensible as Apache JMeter. It’s also impossible to capture a browser session without Visual Studio; it’s format is proprietary. Visual Studio online supports the use of .har files to drive cloud-based load tests, but again, there are limitations. First, you can only test systems open to the public internet.
